verses.text: Hear my prayer, O LORD; let my cry for help come to you.
verses.comment: The psalmist begins seeking God’s attention and mercy. The personal appeal to the LORD is consistent with many psalms of lament.

verses.text: Do not hide your face from me in the day of my distress. Incline your ear to me; answer me quickly when I call.
verses.comment: The imagery of God's face and attentive ear suggests nearness and personal relationship. It also points to the practice of seeking God especially in trials.

verses.text: For my days pass away like smoke, and my bones burn like a furnace.
verses.comment: The language is poetic and highlights the brevity and suffering of human life.

verses.text: My heart is struck down like grass and has withered; I forget to eat my bread.
verses.comment: The psalmist's sorrow is so deep that it affects his physical health. Often, grief leads to fasting, a spiritual practice seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Because of my loud groaning my bones cling to my flesh.
verses.comment: Deep sorrow produces bodily affliction, showing the unity of body and soul common in scriptural anthropology.

verses.text: I am like a desert owl of the wilderness; I have become like an owl among the ruins.
verses.comment: The mention of solitary birds symbolizes isolation and abandonment, feelings common to those enduring great suffering.

verses.text: I lie awake; I am like a lonely bird on a housetop.
verses.comment: This verse continues the theme of loneliness, anticipating Christ’s own experience of abandonment (see Matthew 26:38).

verses.text: All day long my enemies taunt me; those who deride me use my name as a curse.
verses.comment: Being reviled by enemies is a common theme, recognizing the suffering righteous as types of Christ (Psalm 69:21; Matthew 27:39).

verses.text: For I eat ashes like bread and mingle my drink with tears,
verses.comment: Ashes symbolize mourning and repentance. This deep lament recalls practices of penance customary in Israelite worship.

verses.text: Because of your indignation and anger; for you have taken me up and cast me down.
verses.comment: The psalmist attributes suffering ultimately to God’s sovereign plan, yet in relationship—God both lifts and humbles.

verses.text: My days are like an evening shadow; I wither away like grass.
verses.comment: Again, the fleetingness of life is compared to a shadow, a common Hebrew poetic image for human frailty.

verses.text: But you, O LORD, are enthroned forever; your remembrance endures to all generations.
verses.comment: This marks a shift from the psalmist’s despair to praise of God’s eternal kingship. This enduring throne points forward to the promise of David’s everlasting kingdom fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: You will rise and have compassion on Zion, for it is time to show favor to her; the appointed time has come.
verses.comment: God’s special love for Zion and the ‘appointed time’ reveal a pattern of salvation history. The restoration of Jerusalem prefigures God’s ultimate gathering of His people.

verses.text: For your servants hold her stones dear and have pity on her dust.
verses.comment: Love of the physical city echoes the importance of tangible expressions of faith. God cares for His people in body and spirit.

verses.text: So the nations will fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth your glory.
verses.comment: Universal worship is foretold here, foreshadowing the worldwide mission. This expectation reverberates through Christ’s call to all nations (Matthew 28:19).

verses.text: For the LORD builds up Zion; he appears in his glory.
verses.comment: God manifests his presence in the restoration of Zion. His glory among His gathered people is a type of the Incarnation (John 1:14).

verses.text: He regards the prayer of the destitute and does not despise their plea.
verses.comment: The Lord’s compassion is directed to the humble who rely on Him in prayer—affirming the role of intercessory prayer throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Let this be written for a future generation, so that a people yet to be created may praise the LORD:
verses.comment: The psalmist intends his lament and praise for succeeding generations—anticipating the ongoing community of faith across time.

verses.text: For he looked down from the height of his sanctuary; from heaven the LORD viewed the earth,
verses.comment: God’s transcendence does not make Him distant, but cause for reverence. He involves Himself in earthly history for His people’s sake.

verses.text: to hear the groaning of the prisoner, to set free those doomed to death,
verses.comment: Deliverance is central to God’s plan. Christ explicitly fulfills this, proclaiming liberty to captives (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: that men may declare the name of the LORD in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Praise finds its fullness in the public worship of God’s people—foreshadowing the unique role of communal worship.

verses.text: when peoples and kingdoms gather together to worship the LORD.
verses.comment: This anticipates the ingathering of all nations, which finds expression in Christ’s work (see Revelation 7:9–10).

verses.text: He has broken my strength in midcourse; he has shortened my days.
verses.comment: In God’s providence, human plans and life are always subject to His wisdom and authority.

verses.text: "O my God," I say, "do not take me away in the midst of my days— your years continue through all generations."
verses.comment: The psalmist contrasts human mortality with God’s eternal nature, a distinction later echoed in the Letter to the Hebrews (Hebrews 1:10–12), affirming Christ’s divinity.

verses.text: Of old you laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of your hands.
verses.comment: Creation language found here is later applied to Christ as the eternal Son (see Hebrews 1:10–12).

verses.text: They will perish, but you remain; all of them will wear out like a garment. You will change them like a robe, and they will pass away,
verses.comment: God’s immutability is contrasted with the created order’s transience. Hebrews applies this to Christ, affirming his eternal nature and divine sovereignty.

verses.text: but you are the same, and your years will have no end.
verses.comment: God’s unchanging nature is a reassurance to believers. The same faithfulness is seen in Christ (Hebrews 13:8).

verses.text: The children of your servants shall continue; their offspring shall be established before you.
verses.comment: God’s promise extends to future generations. Faithfulness is understood here as both individual and communal, linking with the biblical idea of a people gathered and established in covenant worship.
